reviewText: There was a time when Saturday Night Live went on that parties would stop to watch the show, a time when the guests were acts that might not ordinarily be seen on TV, a time before it was SNL, and Dan Ackroyd was thin.Saturday Night Live the Complete First Season 1975-1976 has just about every show or sketch that made Saturday Night Live legendary. Richard Pryor on the 7th episode in the word association skit with Chevy Chase. There are the sketches and characters that became instant classic's and we still recognize The Bee's, Belushi's Samurai, Emily Littela, Baba Wawa,  and, of course, Weekend Update.Watching the first season is also a chance to watch Saturday Night Live evolve, as the they work out the format before it became formula. The second episode is almost all Paul Simon and his musical guests including Art Garfunkle and Randy Newman. The Not Ready for Prime Time Players weren't the stars of the show (they didn't even get singled out in the credits until February of 76), the guest hosts were. Saturday Night was a chance for the guest hosts like George Carlin to come on and do a longer set of their acts than other late night variety/talk shows like The Tonight Show.Some of the material and references in a few of the skits are dated and of the moment such as, "The Claudine Longet Invitational," The Muppets seem oddly out of place. But the strength of the shows are the sketches and they're still laugh out loud funny, such as, John Belushi's Star Trek parody.The musical guests were hipper than your average show including the afore mentioned Paul Simon, Carly Simon, Jimmy Cliff, Janis Ian, Phoebe Snow, Patti Smith, John Sebastian, Rita Coolidge, Al Jarreau to mention only a few. Saturday Night also had semi-regular appearances of the soon to be famous, such as, Albert Brooks, Andy Kaufman, and Toni Basil.Special features include the screen tests of all The Not Ready for Prime Time Players after they were cast for the show, and an appearance on Tom Synder's Tomorrow show.Watching Saturday Night Live the First Season is the chance to remember Generalismo Francisco Franco is still dead.
summary: When Saturday Night Live Was Funny!

reviewText: Many remember Martin & Rowan's Laugh-In and the British-based Monty Python. On October 11,1975,a legacy began which continues today. Canadian Lorne Michaels launched NBC's Saturday Night(the original name) at 11:30 PM,eastern standard time,applying to New York where this comedy-variety ninety-minute show was based. Michaels carefully assembled his first team consisting of American and Canadian comedians. The American members are John Belushi,who died in 1982 of a drug overdose,Jane Curtin,Garrett Morris,the only black member,Laraine Newman of Los Angeles and Chevy Chase. Dan Aykroyd and Gilda Radner who succumbed to ovarian cancer in 1989,were the Canadians and veterans of Second City TV. Newman was a founding member of a comedy troupe called The Groundlings,which caught Michaels' attention seeing them in a Los Angeles Comedy Club. Billy Crystal nearly made the first SNL team,but was rejected just before premiere time(Crystal,late of TV's "Soap" and currently one of Hollywood's biggest film stars,finally joined for one season in 1984-85). This legendary show begins with Belushi and the late Michael O'Donoghue,one of the writers, in a skit called "The Wolverines". O'Donoghue played a psychiatrist and Belushi was a patient. Belushi became so wild and then Chase,wearing a headset,delivered the first beginning announcement,"LIVE FROM NEW YORK,IT'S SATURDAY NIGHT!". Chase gained an abundance of notoriety on SNL. He was the first Weekend Update anchorman and did quite a few rehearsed pratfalls. He didn't stay long,for as he left SNL just after the second season premiere for a movie career which still continues today but is no longer persistent. Fame from SNL brought Aykroyd,Belushi and Radner,for a while,to filmdom. SNL's first guest host was comedian George Carlin and the first musical guests were Janis Ian and the late Billy Preston. Almost every subsequent show had one or two guest hosts and musical guests. Following Carlin this season were Rob Reiner,Paul Simon,Candice Bergen,the late Richard Pryor and the recently departed Peter Boyle,to name a few. On Reiner's show, which aired via satellite like the other preceding and following shows,he,with his then-wife Penny Marshall,half-angrily exclaimed his disdain for the Bees skit,one of the regulars. Belushi apologized for "ruining the show". How about the man-eating shark skit,inspired by the then-new hit movie JAWS? Simon with Art Garfunkel,performed MY LITTLE TOWN and THE BOXER,on the second show. The other shows were awesome.
summary: Live from New York to where you're viewing,it Saturday Night anytime!

reviewText: For several years, I stayed up well past 2am on Saturday nights hoping to catch reruns of the classic, full SNL shows from 1975-1980. NBC was re-airing some of these great programs in their entirety (not "best of" packages) with few exceptions, starting in the late 1990s in most NBC outlets. Unfortunately, the original cast shows were the exception and the Dana Carvey and/or Will Farrell years were the norm. After several years, I managed to videotape about 25-30 original cast shows, but only about 4 from the first season.Younger audiences unfamiliar with the original SNL will likely be surprised by a number of things in viewing this great collection. Firstly, for those of us who remember, SNL was the most weird and cutting-edge show to be found in those days. The concept of "late night" television was certainly not then what it is today either. There really is no "late night" anymore, what with hundreds of cable/satellite channels and the Internet to keep us entertained around the clock. In the '70s, however, late night was a wasteland of old movies and reruns. Most stations ended their broadcast day by about 1 or 2am (for the tech-geners, this means the three network stations, one public station and typically about 3 or 4 local stations). As far as the networks were concerned, Johnny Carson owned the airways after the local news; this was literally true in many ways. Although not on air during the weekend, Carson Productions was quite a powerful entity, owning many weekend program slots. Beyond local news & the Tonight Show, there was little interest in developing a "late night" program. Secondly, SNL had huge shock value for a culture that wasn't used to seeing risqué material paraded constantly on broadcast TV. For that stuff, most of us had to go to the movies for "un-edited" material. VCRs were not yet in every household and cable was only available in limited format in markets like New York. In the culture that was then, SNL's impact was enormous, providing essential "water cooler" chat on Monday morning. It was what people stayed home for on Saturday nights. It was really the only "hip" show on TV.The Not Ready for Primetime Players were a product of the counterculture 1960s. Much of their humor - especially the now surprising amount of drug references - will seem not only brazenly un-PC (thank heaven!), but incredibly raw for those used to the, ironically, structured and institution-ized nature of the show today. In this sense, the first season shows will not only appear dated, but also register way over-the-heads of most younger viewers. SNL has always been and always will be a victim of instant-datedness, in large part due to one of their greatest attributes: topical comedy. Even some of us still familiar with the pressing issues of the 70s may have a hard time remembering every reference!These earlier shows are also striking in their experimentation. The format we now know & love was at least two seasons in the making. The cast themselves were not considered as the main draw, amazingly enough, and their presence in the first few shows is remarkably sparse. In fact, the second episode is largely music-oriented. Many creative techniques were tried, and some fail miserably. Watch how poorly Abba (although a good performance) are incorporated into an already-in-progress Robert Klein skit. Fast forward past the Muppets if you will...or, if you found them humorous & innovative, as I did, marvel at Jim Henson's shocking (for him anyway) use of drug-related humor! No matter what the result, it's great to see a show daring enough to explore such diverse elements of entertainment, from short films, stand-up comedy, audience participation, to the even occasional use of dramatic device & pathos in the skits. All these things are largely verboten on the show today. Fondly remember a time when often obscure musical guests were chosen for their performance chops and uniqueness, and rarely their pop status, let alone how well they could lip synch (oddly this was not completely true with Abba...but that's a long story!). And of course, relish forever the genius blend of Chase, Belushi, Aykroyd, Radner, Curtain, Newman and the unsung Garret Morris.

It is a joy to see how some things became immediately popular and reworked into the show in later episodes and season. What a terrific way to reward loyal followers. SNL's early years had some bumps in the road, but it hits it's stride in the late 70s. Don't give up on it because of a lame skit or show here and there. They were not all perfect just like today's SNL (or especially like today's SNL).Favorite episode so far: when Paul Simon hosted the 2nd show. reviewText: If you want to know where the U.S. was culturally and politically post-Watergate, you need look no further than season one of Saturday Night Live. You might say that the 60's didn't happen to America outside of special enclaves such as San Francisco until the 70's, and this show was part of that revolution.In 1975, NBC was at the bottom of the then three-network barrel. Their only real hit show was Johnny Carson's "Tonight Show". So In 1974, when NBC Tonight Show host Johnny Carson requested that the weekend broadcasts of "Best of Carson" come to an end so that he could take 2 weeknights off and air repeats on those nights rather than on the weekend, NBC had no alternative but to comply with their star's wishes. To fill the gap, Lorne Michaels was hired to produce a new late-night show for the Saturday slot, and "Saturday Night Live" was born.Michaels fought and cajoled network executives to accept his vision for the show, which was far removed from standard variety-show conventions. For example, one network executive, visiting a dress rehearsal, noticed that the band was in blue jeans and asked when their tuxedos would arrive. Before the show began Michaels had remarked that he knew what the "ingredients (of the show) would be, but not the proportions," and that the show would have to "find itself" on-air. Indeed, the Not Ready for Primetime Players were hardly featured in the premiere, but quickly became the focus of the show, with the guest host and musical act playing a secondary role. Albert Brooks and the Muppets were also dropped after the first season.As other reviewers have mentioned, if you weren't old enough to follow politics or popular culture in 1975, you aren't going to get the jokes in their entirety like you would if you were old enough. Fortunately, even if you are younger, you are in for quite a few musical treats as the musical guests are outstanding - Billy Preston performs "Nothing for Nothing"; Janis Ian performs "At Seventeen"; Paul Simon performed "Still Crazy After All These Years" and "Loves Me Like A Rock" solo and "The Boxer" and "Scarborough Fair" with Art Garfunkel;ABBA performed "Waterloo" and "S.O.S."; and The Stylistics performed "You Make Me Feel Brand New." These are all mainstream 70's songs and performers that should be recognizable to almost anyone. Musical guest appearances on TV may seem like no big deal in the age of the iPod, but in 1975 such appearances were treasured.However, if you are younger, you are going to miss out on some of the hard-biting political satire, including Chevy Chase's hilarious imitations of then President Ford featuring him constantly tripping over things, talking with the phone receiver inverted, and repeatedly telling a ceramic dog placed near his desk "Down Liberty, Down! Good Dog!" Also, the significance of certain guests such as President Ford's press secretary Ron Nessen will escape younger viewers - nobody under 40 who isn't a political science major is going to know who he is. Many elements of the regularly featured news skit "Weekend Update, which paved the way for shows such as "The Daily Show", will not be familiar to under-40 viewers such as the "Ferdinand Francisco Franco is still dead" remark that Chevy Chase keeps making. You'll find the original cast as "The South American Killer Bees" hilarious, but you probably won't know that at the time there actually was a scare that a particular poisonous and aggressive species of bee might migrate north from South America and start attacking Americans. I could go on and on, but you get the picture.One of my favorite "characters", who makes his first appearance in a short skit in episode 15 of the first season, is "Mr. Bill". Mr. Bill is the clay figurine star of what at first appears to be a children's show. Each Mr. Bill episode would start innocently enough, but would quickly turn dangerous for Mr. Bill. Along with his dog, Spot, he would suffer various indignities inflicted by Mr. Hands, a man seen only as a pair of arms. Although often the abuse would ostensibly come from the mean Sluggo, another clay figure character. The violence would inevitably escalate, generally ending with Mr. Bill being crushed or dismembered while squealing, "Ohhhh noooooooooooooo...." It is like seeing the claymation duo of Davey and Goliath being run over and crushed by a tank, and is typical of the great "nothing is sacred" attitude this show had.In summary, old or young, I would say this is a definitely essential purchase. If you're older you'll just get more out of the show because you'll likely remember the context of it all.
summary: A good look at U.S. culture and comedy immediately post-Watergate

The comedy of John Belushi and company sticks out, The writers and producers were inventing the show as they went along, so comedy wasn't always prominent in some shows. Gilda Radner is a bit player at first, but the promise was to be redeemed. Dan Aykroyd was very much a work in progress and so too was Larane Newman. Garrett Morris was at the top of his form and sadly, was not to rise to the heights of the other performers. Richard Pryor's guest shot is a keeper,and how- his "Samurai Hotel", with Belushi is the stuff of legend! Music lovers will cringe at some of the disco music (Jazz great Esther Phillips was awful in singing disco-she should have stuck to jazz!) polluting the era, but Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel sang for the last time on TV on Saturday Night and not again. Chevy Chase is not for everyone, but his opening falls were egarly anticipated. reviewText: I was 12 years old when "NBC Saturday Night" began airing in 1975.  I remember my uncle saying that the Not-Ready-for-Prime-Time Players were "in poor taste and didn't care" (he meant it as a complement).  After that, I would stay up on weekends to enjoy the show whenever I could.  After so much time, I wasn't sure whether these programs would live up to my fond memories of them, so I was very pleased to see that for the most part they do.  It's great to see comedians like Dan Ackroyd and John Belushi at the beginning of their careers, not mention guest stars like Andy Kaufman and George Carlin.  There are some terrific performances from musicians who were at their zenith in the 70s, like Janis Ian, Leon Redbone, Carly Simon, and Gordon Lightfoot.Late night programming was a new thing, and it's interesting to watch the format evolve.  There was a lot of experimentation.  Along with the comedy, there were also bits that went for pathos and conceptual comedy rather than big laughs, which sometimes makes the show seem rather innocent when compared with today's hip, ironic sensibility.  At other times, it displays a harder edge with drug humor that has gone out of fashion in this PC era.  I was even shocked to see John Belushi post a picture of a bare breasted woman in full view of the camera during the "Samurai General Practitioner" sketch with Kris Kristofferson.An entertaining and interesting look into the early days of late night programming.

reviewText: When I found out that the entire first season of "Saturday Night Live" was about to be released to DVD, I was beside myself with excitement! Why? Because I have some great memories of growing up with this hilarious, revolutionary show in it's very early years.I was 13 years old and pretty much spent my boring weekend nights babysitting for extra cash. The kids I sat for forced me to sit through endless torturous hours of "The Love Boat" and "Fantasy Island" (Ugghh!! I'm still having Charo flashbacks!!). But once the kiddies went to bed and 11:30 PM rolled around, something magical and exciting seemed to finally happen on the tube."Saturday Night Live" was a TV show, that seemed like a hip, super cool club, that everyone wanted to be a part of. The fact, that it was being broadcast live, seemed to give it an almost dangerous quality. The humour was revolutionary with lots of references to sex, drugs and rock n' roll. (Hardly the stuff, that my middle aged, parents found remotely funny.) This truely was the first network TV show brought to you by the babyboom generation, who had grown up with television.The guest hosts were celebrities you didn't ordinarily see to often on network television (Elliot Gould, George Carlin, Robert Klein, Richard Pryor ETC.). The same went for the musical acts, that prominently featured rock, jazz and R&B; music (Paul Simon, Patti Smith, Joe Cocker, Jimmy Cliff, Leon Redbone, Carly Simon, Esther Phillips, Phoebe Snow ETC.)But the real draw was the supporting cast, that went on to become stars in their own right. Out of all the talent to come across the NBC 8H stage, that original cast of Dan Aykryod, Chevy Chase, John Belushi, Laraine Newman, Garrett Morris and Gilda Radner (and lets not forget Bill Murray, who eventually joined them) truely had a special comic chemistry, that I don't think has ever beeen replicated.Now, the entire first season has been released to the DVD format. Each episode clocks in around the 66 minute mark. The remastering of the picture & sound is wonderful. Its hard to believe this comes from video tape, that is over thirty years old. It also appears that Producer Lorne Michaels has gotten most of those pesky music clearences, that seem to bedevil many older TV shows going to DVD these days. If I had but one complaint, it is that they removed the show's color tinted photos, that use to signify a commercial break. It's shame those celebrity photos are missing, because they truely were part of the show's look and character.Nobody is going to argue that every single show is a classic (certainly not the Rob Reiner episode). But the vast majority of them will give most viewers some big belly laughs and even a sense of nostalgia. If you are a fan of SNL or just good comedy in general, then highly recommend the DVD box set "Saturday Night Live: The Complete First Season".
summary: "It's a Floor Wax...No It's a Desert Topping!!"

reviewText: "...and wonder if they're dead yet?" -- George Carlin, Episode 1 of SNL"Saturday Night Live -- The Complete First Season" is perhaps the most magical multi-DVD set it has been my privilege to watch.  It proves that any sufficiently long-running TV show, no matter how frivolous in its nature, ultimately becomes a kind of saga in which early episodes inevitably foreshadow later events, whether in the TV show itself or in culture in general.  To name just one example, when Simon and Garfunkel sing "The Boxer" in Episode 2, one cannot help remembering that Paul Simon would sing that song again twenty-six years later on the first SNL after 9/11.Is "The Complete First Season" funny?  Yes, it is -- obviously not continuously or perfectly funny, perhaps not even as funny as "The Complete Twelfth Season" (Dana Carvey's first) would be, but funny enough to keep me laughing aloud throughout the 66 minutes of each of the 24 episodes (with the obvious exception of Episode 2, the mostly-music presentation hosted by Paul Simon -- probably the only SNL episode ever that can be described as "tranquil" and "calming").But what makes this set most special to me is the patina of irony and poignancy that these episodes have acquired over the years.  There are so many moments that now carry far more significance than they would have in 1975-1976.  Some such moments are hilarious (an ad for a "Triple-Trak" razor as a piece of satire).  Some are bittersweet (John and Gilda's unforgettable, totally wordless "Laundromat" sketch).  Some are so tragic in retrospect that they are hard to watch -- most of all, Emily Litella declaring that cancer research is "very necessary".I strongly recommend that viewers take the time to watch all of these episodes in broadcast order, to see the series' familiar format develop and to understand how the American public gradually came to know these seven unknown performers.  (At the end of "Citizen Kane II", when the actors' names appear on screen in a parody of "Citizen Kane"'s closing credits, I realized with a shock that that would have been the first time many viewers found out which one was Belushi and which one was Aykroyd.)  But however you watch, there are few other DVD boxed sets which I can recommend so confidently.

reviewText: I never thought entire seasons of "Saturday Night Live" would ever be released on DVD.  Never in a million years.  Never in my wildest dreams. But lo and behold, here it is.  And all I can say is "Wow".I don't think I began watching SNL on a regular basis until its second season when Bill Murray joined the show and The Coneheads first appeared and Steve Martin began hosting.  So it was fascinating for me to watch the show's first season in order to see the transformation of this landmark series.  The first few episodes aren't that great or funny.  The Not Ready for Prime Time Players weren't allowed to really shine until around the fourth episode when Candice Bergen hosted.  And the second show with Paul Simon as host is almost all music--which isn't bad--but it's not the SNL we came to know and love.  But slowly as the season evolved, the original cast became stars and the main reason to tune in.Dan Aykroyd, John Belushi, Jane Curtin, Garrett Morris, Chevy Chase, Laraine Newman and Gilda Radner took over SNL and made it their own during the first season.  They developed classic characters such as Gilda's Emily Litella and Baba Wawa (Barbara Walters), Chevy's accident-prone President Ford, Land Shark (a spoof of the popular "Jaws") and his smooth Weekend Update newscaster, Dan's Jimmy Carter and Richard Nixon, and John's Japanese Samurai, plus The Bees.  Even The Muppets showed up during the first season, but they were eventually phased out as the cast became more popular--and their humor didn't really fit the show that well (and it was all for the best, since The Muppets then went on to create their own popular show, "The Muppet Show").I confess I haven't watched SNL much since the days of Eddie Murphy and The Sweeney Sisters (Nora Dunn and Jan Hooks).  After they all left, so did I.  But I think it's amazing that the show is still on the air after all these years.  That's what makes this first season so special--to see the roots of such a legendary show.  I loved the eclectic mix of guest hosts--Rob Reiner, Candice Bergen, Lily Tomlin, Richard Pryor, Elliott Gould, Buck Henry, Dick Cavett, Desi Arnaz (who is wonderful), Jill Clayburgh, Anthony Perkins, Raquel Welch, Madeline Kahn, Dyan Cannon and Louise Lasser--and the musical guests are just as diverse: Janis Ian, Simon & Garfunkel, Abba, Anne Murray, Neil Sedaka, Patti Smith Group, Carly Simon, Gordon Lightfoot, Loudon Wainwright III (Rufus' father) and Rita Coolidge.  Wow.  I have to say that again.  Wow.  And again.Also, this DVD set includes some interesting extras: the original screen tests for the cast and an interview with the cast and producer Lorne Michaels on NBC's "Tomorrow Show" starring Tom Snyder just before the first episode aired.If you want to watch a groundbreaking show become a force of nature, here's where it all began.  Right here--on this DVD set.  And be sure to watch the episodes in order.  It's a fascinating journey.

reviewText: I must say that it is absolutely great that we can finally see the shows as they were originally broadcast (minus the 25 minutes of commercials that I hated sitting through).  This is SNL in its prime.  In seeing these uncut shows, you will see just how good the original cast was.  Just one show from this season is better than any yearly "Best Of" they can put together from the current cast.THE DOWN SIDE: There has been little effort made to restore the 30+ year old videotapes.  The picture is often soft with color bleeding to the right of objects on screen. This is not the original way we saw the series live, so some restoration would have been nice.  Other shows have gotten better DVD treatment.WHAT YOU SHOULD KNOW if you never saw the first season live:1) Take away the 25 minutes of commercials and these "90 Minute" shows only run 65 minutes.2) In those days the show was NOT called "Saturday Night Live", that title was used by sportscaster Howard Cosell for his weekly live vartiety show seen at 9pm, Saturday Nights on the ABC Network.  This show's first season was officially called "NBC's Saturday Night" and introduced as "Live from New York, it's NBC's Saturday Night".  These original titles were later re-shot as just "Saturday Night" for the hour long syndication run, and "The Best Of Saturday Night Live" for the later cut-down half hour syndication run.3) While the first show seems to be a in the regular sketch format, the second show is more of a Paul Simon Special with Chevy Chase making a brief appearance to introduce the show, and later to do a "Weekend Update".  The "Not Ready For Prime Time Players" make brief appearances in filmed segments.  The third show returns to the familiar sketch format, but the end credits roll over a slide of the guest star rather than have everyone waving "by" on stage.  It is apparent that NBC was still finding the style & format for the show.4) Season 1 was the only season with Chevy Chase as a regular, after that he would appear as a guest star.5) Bill Murray was not a regular in the first season.
summary: Restored to original format & titles, but no technical restoration.

reviewText: These DVD sets are a wonderful time capsule of 70's pop culture.Early vintage SNL was truly cutting-edge, envelope pushing humor.  A lot of the sketches could never get past the censors today because of political correctness and corporate sensitivities.Along with all of the timeless goofy situation humor, the cast, writers, and producer poked fun at their own network, delivered plenty of below-the-belt political satire, gave Cheech & Chong a run for their money at drug humor, dabbled with some occasionally dicey racial humor, and even made comic sport of a pedophile (Buck Henry's "Uncle Roy," who doesn't show up until Season 4).Some of the humor may not translate smoothly to the more cautiousworld of today.  All I can say is, you had to be there.Regardless of the level of celebrity they had obtained, the musical guests were always first-rate.  Their performances alone are worth the price of these sets.It's sadly ironic that the very people who made us laugh so hysterically were themselves so often quite miserable in the moment; for SNL was then and is now a crucible of competitive juices and often conflicting egos fueled by enormous time pressures and the fragile, terrifying exhilaration of the live performance.
summary: Like stepping into a time machine

reviewText: Looking back on stand-up comedy, sketch comedy, and even improv comedy, as they exist today, there is no doubt where the dividing line is drawn, separating the "current" from everything that came before it.  The first season of SNL is that dividing line.  This is the first time the Baby Boomers, the Sixties Kids, the people that were handed a Golden Plastic Suburban Society and rejected it wholesale, were given control of a show.  Fortunately, at that time, light night TV was a wasteland, a virtual graveyard of test patterns, or, if an insomniac was lucky, old black and white movies.  The "suits" weren't paying attention to what the "kids" were doing with their airwaves at 11:30 on a Saturday.  At the time, hard-to-believe as it may be, there was no cable, no satellite, and no internet.  SNL was the first time America at large got a look at anything even close to subversive on the airwaves.Of course, even SNL didn't come out of nowhere.  Even SNL had influences, the biggest two of which were Monty Python's Flying Circus (for its looney, jovial anarchy), and the early National Lampoon magazine empire(for its looney, drug-addled anarchy).  SNL and that golden original cast didn't exactly invent comedy, they just were given the perfect platform to take over the position of most influential purveyors of comedy on the pop culture landscape.And what a cast it was!  The smarmy WASP banter of Chevy Chase, the lovably spastic wailings of Gilda Radner, the various sleazy characters personified by Dan Ackroyd, and the manic blustery energy brought to the stage by Belushi.  It is true that the first season will be a shock to many; the format was not quite yet established and was more of a variety show.  It wasn't even called Saturday Night Live!  It was called NBC's Satruday Night, since there was another show (a variety show of the traditional stripe) on ABC called Saturday Night Live that was hosted by (get ready) Howard Cosell!  So this first season might be shocking to some (younger) viewers; but you can see the potential for greatness there, right from the first sketch, which honestly, is a bit of a rip-off of the Monty Python "Hungarian phrasebook" sketch.  But soon enough, the cast members found their own notes and bits, they fired The Muppets, and the legend was born for the rest of the Scary 70's.SNL has been a good companion over the years.  I saw that first show when it originally aired, at age nine (I sneaked my viewing in my bedroom with the covers over my head), and have always come back to it time and again, even if I didn't see every single show.Even the worst shows SNL ever did provide entertainment, or comedy, be it intentional or not.  Going back and looking at the full shows at this late date will allow the viewer to realize that not everything the original cast did back then was gold.  They did bomb out from time to time with unfunny material; it's just the funny stuff that gets remembered in the haze of golden nostalgia.  But still, it's great to have it all, funny, not funny, the whole ball of wax, even the musical guests, available to pull off the shelf at a whim.  If you have any regard at all for comedy, this is a MUST BUY.  A MANDATORY PURCHASE.  Get it now.
summary: This is Ground Zero for Comedy, Folks

reviewText: Attitude. Youthful energy. In-fighting. Intelligence. Diversity. These are the things that make the early years of SNL legendary. This is a time capsule back to when the show had a punk rock/ underground edge. There are clever references to drugs, sex and politics during a turbulent era in American culture. Alot of the jokes backfire and its apart of the beauty of the show. Its live and all of the blemishes are out in the open. I only wish there was more spontaneity in modern entertainment.The current incarnation of SNL suffers from predictability and one-dimension of humor. Here we have slapstick, serio-comedy, vaudeville, politcal satire, etc. The hosts actually had an impact on the tone and style of each episode. Richard Pryor, Madeline Kahn and Peter Cook/Dudley Moore are stand-outs. One can't overlook the magic of the "Not Ready for Primetime Players." Gilda and John have a familiar charm that is world famous, but they are my least favorite performers (Emily LaTella and Baba Wawa are one-joke characters would shouldn't have lasted longer than this season. Ugh). But now, as the show has aged, you can admire the subtle talents of people like Laraine Newman, Garrett Morris and Michael O'Donoghue. Each cast member brings a unique energy to the sketch. And I have to defend the star power of Chevy Chase who's Weekend Update and his occasional slapstick genius elevated the show. Dan Aykroyd and Jane Curtin are the most consistent performers and would remain so for years.I actually enjoy the "clunker" skits and the "boring" short films. I appreciate the different rhythms in these early episodes.  But the Muppets blow. But the No. 1 thing I love about early SNL is the broad, clever concepts behind the sketches. This was before the recurring characters and catchphrases dominated Lorne Michaels' vision. No polish, fearless topics and inspired performances. I just wish it could have lasted longer than a few seasons.

reviewText: Saturday Night Live premiered in the fall of 1975. At that time, the show broke new ground in the otherwise stale, late-night TV landscape. It was fresh, cutting-edge, and boiling-over with it's unprecedented brand of risqué humor.It's target audience, was mainly the teen and twenty-something 70s baby-boomers. These viewers finally had a comedy show, that they could instantly relate to. It poked fun at everything their parent's generation tended to take too seriously; religion, politics, social proprieties, etc.It goes without saying, that the splendidly talented Not Ready For Prime Time Players, were the centerpiece of the show. They included Chevy Chase, Dan Akroid, John Belushi, Gilda Radner, Jane Kurtin, Garrett Morris, and Lorraine Newman. When they left the show after the first few seasons, it never quite regained it's comedic edge, that it had when they were regulars.Saturday Night Live also had the hippest guest hosts every week. These various hosts, always seemed to mesh marvelously with the overall comedic hi-jinx of the show.During it's early years, and even today, Saturday Night Live has featured some of the most cutting-edge musical performers; Patti Smith (the 'godmother' of Punk), Run DMC, Queen Latifah, The Talking Heads, Nirvana, etc. So the musical performance segment of the show, was always as much of a treat as the comedic sketches were.In summation, Saturday Night Live was the original template, for all of the irreverent comedy sketch shows that came later; SCTV, The Kids In The Hall, Mad TV, etc. And though the first few seasons of the show were the best, it still holds its own, even after being on the air nearly 33 years now.
summary: Template for the irreverent comedy show genre.

reviewText: Saturday Night's format was in flux during 1975 and 1976. The series was originally touted as a comedy/variety show (rather than a sketch comedy series). Today's viewers may find the amount of music surprising, but it was an essential part of the show. For a lot of people at the time, the rock music was the main attraction.Yes, it all looks very 1970s, and yes, the topical jokes are now dated. But, of course, it WAS the '70s, so that's to be expected.There are a few good episodes here, including a great early one hosted by Lily Tomlin and a fun broadcast hosted by Peter Cook and Dudley Moore. Also of interest is the show hosted by White House Press Secretary Ron Nessen (with some classic skits and with brief filmed appearances by President Ford).These DVDs are, however, a mixed bag as entertainment. There are memorable skits, but also a lot of humor that falls flat (especially some of the Albert Brooks films and anything involving people in bee costumes). Still, I'm having a great time watching even the weaker programs. The quality of the comedy improves as the season progresses.My main complaint is the picture quality, which is rather smeary and suffers significant loss of color detail on a lot of the episodes.Among other issues, there's major "crushing" of the darker colors, with people's hair and dark clothing occasionally disappearing into the background. There are also image distortions and far too many cases of juddery movement (which are surely the result of poor DVD authoring rather than flaws on the source tape). The video problems are worse than I've seen on other 1970s series, and they add to the sense of datedness. Nonetheless, I'm thrilled to finally have the whole first season of this groundbreaking series, which redefined late-night TV.
summary: Finally, season one! A mixed bag as entertainment. Problematic video quality.

People seem to have the idea that EVERYTHING the original cast did was great. Everything was classic, every episode.Boy, are those people going to be disappointed.
